The war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war before invading Iraq. I think there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality, the two didn't have much to do with each other. But the government made it seem that way and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003. 

I am against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think the war in Iraq is a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. A tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and that's horrible. They were taking out the country's government, and I don't think the American government was prepared for the aftermath, the void of power, and the chaos that would occur.

The United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, similar to what they tried to do in Vietnam. They were trying to push out Communists and uphold or implement democracy. The US government should have known that it would be a long and hard ordeal that probably wouldn't be a clear victory, like Vietnam.

So, when you put something on the internet, it's public. It's completely public. You can't - I mean, as an RA, it's something I've actually had to deal with already. When you put something out there, it influences people's opinions of you. And if you're talking about blowing things up or if you're talking about shootings, someone's going to say something. You can't put that out there, put that into the world. The internet is seen by everyone. If you're friends with that person on Myspace, you get that bulletin. Obviously, it wasn't the school that got the bulletin. Someone went to the school and they have to act on that. They can't let it sit because then, God forbid something does happen, they could have prevented it. [Right]

Again, you don't know what to take seriously because some people just fool around like that. I mean, it could be like the situation we had at school. It could be an experiment that went terribly wrong for a - for a sociology class. Sorry, couldn't remember the word for a minute. And it could also be something very serious. I think what happened here was that something happened and someone overheard someone saying something in the school and then they reported it. When we finally found out who the person was, they looked through a friend of his Facebook and got very worried because there were some things on there that he may have meant as a joke but in light of the situation became very serious.

When you put stuff out into the public forum of the internet, there's really no invasion of privacy that happens. If you don't want it out there, don't put it there. If you don't want someone to find it, if you don't want someone to think something of you, you can't tell them what to think. You can't tell people what to take seriously or not. I mean, I don't think school officials should be friending their students on Myspace and Facebook and stalking and going through Facebooks and Myspaces and all those things and Xangas and Live Journals. But if it is brought to the attention of the school officials, there's really no invasion of privacy there because it's brought by someone who you gave access to it. And if there's danger they have to take it seriously.

I mean, like I said, I don't think they should be monitoring phone conversations and texts and IMs and if it's brought to their attention then it's something completely different.

Um, yeah don't. Like a teacher should not make a Facebook or a Myspace account under a different name and friend their students because then that's just, it's the same thing. I wouldn't friend my residents because frankly I don't want to know if they're going out and drinking and then posting their pictures on Facebook. Then that pops up and I have to see that and I have to do something about it. It's not my place so I don't even want that, that connection there. Um, not really.

Um, I feel like the war has been drawn out far too long. I think the initial goal was good, namely to restore democracy in another country. But I think we have long since lost sight of that goal. And we are maybe just doing it out of principle, just to prove that we are some kind of superpower in the world. I also think that the original motives were questionable, having to do with the previous disputes of George Bush's father with Saddam Hussein. So, I think... I think if the original motivation was to give democracy to a country that did not have a fair political system, then that would be a fair motivation, if there were any personal matters in it, I don't think it would have been fair. But I do think it has dragged on too long. Um, I think we achieved our purpose in the first couple of months when we started the war, I think that was a statement in itself. But the fact that it has lasted for over a year, several years, I just think it's way too drawn out. 

Um, yeah, I think, um, I mean, if our goal was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, then that's a just purpose, and that's a good reason for the war. But I don't think, I think our reason over time has deteriorated and been misunderstood. It seems like we're still at war for the sake of going to war, and we don't want to come out of this thing without a decisive end, a victory or something. 

Um, yeah, I do think it has gone on long enough, and it should stop. I mean, there comes a point when their government, their officials are going to have to fend for themselves anyway, and I think that time has come. We have long since been draining our own economy, spending billions of dollars when we have our own wars on our own turf, such as poverty and so on, that we should be spending that money on. I think it's a drain on our economy for a purpose that's long since been drawn out. 

Yeah, I mean, they're spending billions and billions of dollars, and war is not something that should be in our budget for the long term. There are things obviously like poverty or internal improvements, you know, um, public roads or anything dealing with schools, we certainly have a lot of problems funding things like that. Healthcare, that I think that money could be much better spent on. Right now that money’s being spent to have some of our own citizens killed in a foreign country in a war that we've lost the cause for.

I think that's it.

Can I ask a question to clarify this? Um, it was prevented because someone went online and found that there was something like that. O okay. Um, no, I don't think that's an invasion of privacy. On sites like Myspace, if I mean, if you post information on the internet, it's pretty much available for everyone to see. And I understand on Myspace you know, you have to have someone else be a member in order to see someone's profile. You might need to, you know, be their friend or something like that. But if that's the case, you've accepted that person as your "friend" so they can see it. You're giving them permission to see your profile. So, I mean, anytime you put information on the internet, you pretty much have to understand that a lot of people are going to see that. So if I think that was actually good that somebody saw that and was able to prevent a life from being lost.

Hum. Um, that's tough because I mean obviously you can't have one person sitting around all day looking at everybody's different profiles of all the students in the school to prevent that. But then it becomes some sort of discrimination if they think, "Oh let's look at the bad kids and make sure they're not up to anything". Um, I mean, I don't think it would really be right to go and have somebody's job be to look at peoples' profiles. But I guess it all depends on like what situation they came across that profile, or was someone just randomly looking at peoples' and just randomly happened to see that, or were they actually looking for, you know, some sort of evidence that the student was planning something. So I don't really know.

Sure. Um, well, um, like, I mean I I don't have a Myspace personally but I have a Facebook. I do. It bothers me that I know that there's creepy people out there who can see things about me. And I saw something on tv once that was about this. Um, this man who just, he was just trying to prove how he can get information so easily and he went onto this girl's profile and got her screen name right away and was talking to her on instant messenger in like you know less than a minute and got her to meet with him. And I mean personally I certainly wouldn't meet with someone like that. But I have had people in my classes who I don't recognize their screen names, but they IM me and they know that it's me. And it's hard because you think that they know your interests, they know what you look like. Sometimes if you put your class schedule they know where you are during the day, who your friends are. They pretty much know a lot about you. All sorts of photos. And I tried to limit what I put up there, but at the same time, the whole point I think, the reason I have one is so you know I can communicate with some of my friends. I don't want to limit it too much. So it's a tricky issue because I only accept people I know. I mean, you never know really who can look at what. So.

Hum, uh, well, I heard my roommate was telling me that her, um, high school, there was this whole issue about how students were banned from having Myspace by the school and that struck me as a little bit strange, like I wasn't sure how, how high school officials had the power to tell their students that they weren't allowed to have a Myspace. And I don't know if that's really a privacy issue, but I think, I don't really know, how they had the right to tell people. That's the only other thought I can think of.


Yes.

We only have this and then one more time that I need to talk about the Iraq War. I mean I feel hypocritical talking about it. I mean I hate to say you know, I hate to join the bandwagon of people that are like, oh I was against it from the beginning. Um, I was but like it’s not really important anymore. Cause just the general consensus everywhere was that it was a bad idea except within the administration because they don’t want to admit that they were wrong. And um, I mean you just have to look at like the recent polls. They’ve done United States polls, they’ve done Iraqi polls, they’ve done global polls, and I mean no like about seventy five to eighty percent of the population of the world thinks that it was a bad idea, eighty percent of Iraqis. Um, seventy percent of the troops that are over there, like the U.S. troops that are over there right now think it was a dumb idea and that we should pull out within the year. Um, I don’t know, it’s just been a complete disaster from before we even came in. It was already a disaster and now pulling out is also going to be a disaster. There’s really no easy way to go about really anything involving the Middle East anymore. Um, I mean I think it’s just, just the culture clash between like the United States and the Middle Eastern states. I mean it’s just too big a gap and for like this administration to understand or previous administrations. And they think that they can just like bring democracy into an area where it shouldn’t exist. Like that’s not the way that, um, this totally different group of people would choose to run their lives. I mean sure Saddam was a bad guy, I don’t think anyone’s like arguing that he’s not, but I mean you have to weigh the pros and cons before you invade a country that’s going to, you know, turn into just a complete disaster, just like quicksand from when we went over there. Um, I don’t even know what to say about it. Um, I don’t really see a reason at all to stay in there. Um, I mean I’m sure the administration is thinking some hopeful ideas as to why it’s better to stay in there, um, and you know the problems that might arise from us pulling out. I don’t agree with them. I’ve yet to hear like a legitimate reason why we should stay in any longer than we should. Um, if they want to do it gradually over the course of a year or maybe a little longer than a year, um, I guess I wouldn’t really have a problem with that. But, I just don’t see a reason why we shouldn’t just leave now. Um, I mean I read this statistic a little while ago that eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year and at least a quarter of them think that we should just leave now. And like these, these are the people that we’re trying to save, like that we’re trying to help, telling us to leave. Um, you know I think they might know better than that. And at least if we ask them should we leave and they say yes then you know it’s not on us if something happens. You know if it completely goes to shit we could be like well we were going to stay in but you guys made the decision not to. Um, and then you know at least we’ll, I mean if we decide to help out after that we’ll at least be the good guys. Kind of, not really, no. We’ll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but, you know, it’ll be better than you know where we are, where we stand right now. Um, yeah, uh, no.

I feel that gender discrimination is still a problem in the United States. And it's not just against women. I think it has to do with the specific field of work you are in. I mean, overall, I think women have it harder because of the glass ceiling. Even though equality is supposed to exist, most people have a hard time working under a woman if they are a man, just because of how society has been raised for so long. And so women often see a job they can reach, and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't elect to promote them to that position just because historically, women aren't usually seen in the upper echelons of the business world. And um, I guess the same thing goes for men, and for other industries like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent. It's really uncommon to have a male parent staying at home, and a lot of times people look down on that because society thinks, "Oh, well, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the money maker of your family. Why are you staying at home?" And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them, and maybe the wife has the better job, and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down on that.  And then in the fashion industry, um a lot of times people won't really take males seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion, um, I guess have different lifestyles, and so if you have the typical lifestyle and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, wait, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really know what our situation is like like these other guys." And so depending on what field of work you're in, I feel like there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset, and obviously, we have come a long way from the 1800s, leaps and bounds. But change is really slow, so I feel that if we continue working at the pace we are now because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world, and it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. And just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh, wait, maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works," and um, and then for like fashion, people will be like, "Oh, wait, maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff." And so they do know like where I'm coming from. So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um, saying like the qualities of them because if you force it people are going to resist. And I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that, so I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist, and we've come a long way and change takes time. Yes, um, well I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you go to have yourself, like you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world, and even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like, "Well, how do I know you're really what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?" So, yeah, so sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don't know, I guess that'd be another example, um, not really.

Well, my understanding is that they didn't legalize it. They decriminalized it.  Hmm, that took it down from a criminal offense to, uh, something like a traffic ticket. You know, something you just get cited for rather than having to get booked and arrested and brought in and all of that. Um, and I think that if someone gets caught and gets cited for that, then you know, for the purposes of job interviews and all sorts of things like that, those types of ramifications which are usually like the worst of having a drug charge would, I mean usually the worst ramifications of having a drug charge, well, depending on the charge. At least for a marijuana charge. One thing that a lot of kids worry about, a lot of people worry about are the future ramifications and those don’t necessarily go away when it’s decriminalized. But at the same time there is an argument that, uh, I mean it costs a lot to arrest people and to bring them in and to book them and to house them and then to let them go. And then it costs a lot, you know to have them come into court once, maybe twice, maybe three times and then appoint a public defender and then you have to pay the judge and then the state attorney’s office has to pick up the charge and basically press the charges. I mean all of that stuff costs a lot to do. And um, I mean so, when you’re looking at municipalities that are financially in trouble, I mean a lot of them just philosophically aren’t willing to make that kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them. Like a lot of communities are rightfully so against marijuana that they don’t want to do that. But in a place like Denver where people tend to be more on the kind of open, I have to use the word liberal, but you know what I mean, kind of uh, kind of thought track, then I think it’s totally fine. And I’m sure that their municipality has a lot more money now that they can spend on public education, that they can spend on like social programs for the elderly and that they can spend on, you know, food programs for the homeless people. Um, I mean so, I think it’s, it’s important because I mean marijuana isn’t something that you just want out and out to be everywhere, all over the streets and stuff. Um, I mean for a variety of reasons, but there’s this whole like financial element to it as well. Other reasons why it shouldn’t necessarily, well, no, I mean I, I don’t know how I would feel about, well because if it were totally like legalized, I guess you could make it like cigarettes where it could be sold in gas stations and people would be smoking it everywhere. Then I mean, I guess a lot of people would be like smoking and driving, and um, it still is like taboo in our society, in a lot of places and a lot of contexts, uh, to smoke marijuana. So, to have it out in the open like that, I feel like it would just be awkward to a lot of people. Um, and, sorry what?  The volume on the microphone is kind of low. Um, I don’t really know, um, I think in general alcohol has more debilitating effects on your motor skills. Um, but I think in general marijuana for a lot of people has a more adverse effect on their lifestyle as opposed to just their decision-making motor skills. I mean, but they, they both have their adverse effects and I mean they, I feel like when it comes to substances in general, like no two people really react the same way. I mean, and then people, some people have personalities that are just more normal and they just kind of go balls to wall with everything they have, and then some people know how to exercise moderation and then some people don’t. So it, I guess that makes it really hard to generalize about the substance when people react different ways, but I definitely think that they both have their own adverse effects. Um yeah, uh, no, I don’t.

I would say yes because a lot of the things they do are very traditional, like they’ve done the same things for long periods of time, and it’s good to be rooted in tradition, but it’s also important to be adaptable to change. I guess a lot of Catholics believe they have to go to church every week and they’re very strict on how things are done. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on people who don’t follow the doctrine to a tee and they don’t accept people who aren’t exactly perfect Catholics. They also don’t accept people of other religions. Like, for example, my dad was an Episcopalian and my mom was a Catholic, and they wouldn’t marry my parents in the Catholic Church because of my dad’s religion. And that’s not really being tolerant of other religions. We always learned to love others, that’s a Catholic teaching, but it’s hypocritical to say to love others and then not accept them in that way. So I feel like a lot of Catholic doctrine tells you to do things, but then Catholic practice goes against it because it’s so outdated, but they continue to stick with it anyway. I don’t think that would necessarily influence it. I mean, I personally think it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, but as I don’t think that would necessarily deter them from their pedophilic behavior, because it’s just a different realm. It might, but I probably don’t think that that would be an issue. Well, I guess like people who molest children probably would do that regardless of whether they had a spouse or not, because it’s a child which is different than a spouse. So if you’re going to do something like that, you’re probably going to do it whether or not you’re married. Like, I don’t think allowing priests to be married would prevent those things from happening. I think that would probably happen regardless.

Um, I haven't really made up my mind about this issue yet. So, I can't say if either side is right or wrong. But I believe that this is the trickiest topic we're facing today because something so close between separation of church and state and how to define marriage is something that is very hard to do without offending anyone.

So, I don't know, I think that... all civil unions... I don't know whether marriage should be looked at... and... how it should be defined by the government... Since it is a sacrament like considered... Well, people wouldn't get tax breaks... Or... looked at in any specific way by the government if they were baptized... And... so... If you're married, I think they should just look at it as a civil union... Because... that's what it is... It's two people... They shouldn't have separation of church and state... They shouldn't look into like well what kind of marriage was it... Two people got united... So... and... the fact that gay marriage... I mean... that would just... Oh, two people you got a civil union...

Um... Well, if all the states can come to a logical conclusion then they should push to make it federal law. But... a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is just ridiculous. It is... something like the constitution shouldn't just be amended for something... I mean, it is a very big cause for certain people... But... it's not large enough that it should be a constitutional amendment.

It's just not important enough to amend the constitution... to define... to ban gay marriage. Simply put...

Uh... No.

Um, I was actually raised in a Christian home, so homosexuality is kind of a grey area for me. Because I have a lot of gay friends. Um, I think I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, but I think it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue. However, I believe that it should be something that each state decides on its own, instead of, um, like, the president deciding for the whole country.

Um, like a lot of states are democratic and, and a lot of states are republican. Obviously, democratic states are going to push for gay marriage, and, and if you're living in a democratic state, then you know, obviously, how that state feels about that position. And, and I don't think that you're necessarily in a position to disagree with that decision if a state does decide to legalize gay marriage, because you kind of chose to live there. You know, so I, like, I think, I don't, I think that homosexuals should be given the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel as though it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state.

Well, I kind of already answered that, but, um, yeah, I don't feel as though, um, Bush should be allowed to, um, decide, um, um, that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to the, um, individual states as to whether they want to legalize it. I don't agree with his ban on it.

Um, I just, I just don't think, like, I don't think that, like, Bush doesn't live in every single state. So, he shouldn't be able to decide how each state wants to run, um, run itself, I guess, I don't know, um, so, I think that, um, some things should be left up to, um, each individual state. Plus, he's going to be out of office in like, what, two years, and if a democratic president decides that he wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, like, it's just going to go back and forth. It should just be up to each individual state because they're the ones that are going to have to live with that decision, not the president.

No, I don't.

Um, no, I don't at all. Um, let's see. I figure Myspace is a public thing, and a bulletin board. You know, if you look at the definition, then you know, that's basically to post for the public to see or others to see, whatever you're trying to get at. And, if you post that on the internet, you know, you have to realize that people will be seeing that, whether it be school officials or not. So, in my opinion, I feel as though the school officials seeing that, they had every right to see it because even if they weren't doing it underneath the school's name, they could have still accessed it through their homes. Um, but yeah, with something preventing a school shooting, you know, as long as it saves the lives of students, which is a responsibility of the school system, I think that's perfectly fine. Um, let me see here. Like, um, you know, if they go on the internet like on Myspace just to see if students are drinking, smoking, or doing stuff they're not supposed to be doing, they go on there just specifically to catch students and get them in trouble. And I feel as though that is an invasion of privacy. But, um, I feel as though as long as they save lives or make the school a better and safer place, I don't think that's an invasion at all. Should I elaborate more on that?

Yeah, um, alright. Well, um, hmm, it's a lot easier to express yourself a lot longer when you're writing, but alright, well, like what I was saying, it is a public thing, and with a student posting something on Myspace and not expecting to get in trouble, that's ridiculous. Um, everything, like, I'm worried to post stuff like even through emails. Um, like if I have something not good about somebody to say, I don't ever say that on an email because I'm afraid somebody somehow will pick that up, and you know, everything like everything nowadays comes back and, you know, bites you in the butt I guess you could say. Um, like, you know, if you do something while you're a college student, then you grow up to be some important guy, they will like find an email that you sent somehow, and like once it's on the internet, it's always on the internet, and, um, you know, if you do something like that there's no way of getting out of it; you will get in trouble. And I don't, it wasn't an invasion at all of privacy because, you know, like I said before, and well, that's basically all I've been saying was it's a public thing, and, um, I don't know, let's see here.

 Um, like I had said before, I don't feel as though they should go on the internet just to catch students, but if they have something that leads them to the point where they would be making the school system a safer place, then I feel as though that's perfectly fine for them, or um, other officials such as the police to go on, um, you know, when parents drop their students off at school, they feel as though they're dropping them off at a safe place. I've actually discussed that with a, um, a teacher of mine. I went to a public high school, and um, they say you know, we have to ensure stuff like this because like, we would do like lockdowns and stuff, and that's like in reference to the terrorist attacks. Uh, we had to be safe about that. We had like drill stuff, and even though that doesn't have anything to do with the well I mean it kind of does have something to do with the school shooting because um, that was in case people would come into the building I guess, um, so we, you know, we did practice that stuff um, in order to make the school a safer place, and that's just what the school officials were doing in this case; they were just making it a safer place, preventing anything bad from happening, like Columbine or something like that. Um, yeah, that's basically all I can come up with. Uh, no, that's about it.

Okay, so, at first I was all for the war because 9/11 affected me personally. I was for going over there and causing as much havoc as they did here. I think because it was such an emotional event, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long run. We kind of just went over there unprepared without a plan. And I really think that it backfired on us. Um, I don't know, I was for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it did anything. I think the people there, as long as they're fighting with each other, they can't be fighting with us too. Like, I don't think us being over there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost just, I just don't care about what goes on over there with those people. I just don't care. I just think, I don't think they're human sometimes. I don't know, they fight with each other and they can't, they just can't do anything themselves. So I really don't care. Um, I don't know, we definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face over there. Um, and it's also bad because war for them is very different than war for us. They're just like savage people when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out of there. And I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. Um, we just, I think we were just more hyped up than anything. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle and, um, I just, we pretty much just went over there looking for revenge, I think, and I think President Bush just went over there because pretty much the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. And um, also I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. Um, but at the time I see where he was coming from. We really, I don't think we had a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say ok let's rebuild and that's it. So, um, I don't think we could have let it go. But I think we could have just had a better plan of what we were gonna do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, like creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't, there was no like unity. They didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with. So that's what we created in turn in there. Um, and honestly, I don't, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And um, I don't, I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on definitely long enough. Um, I don't think we're making enough progress. Like we've made progress, but not enough to stay in there. And I think no matter how long we stay in there, once we leave, it's just gonna collapse. And we can't stay over there forever. So I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying over there. No. Okay.

The war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war before invading Iraq. I think there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality, the two didn't have much to do with each other. But the government made it seem that way and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003. 

I am against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think the war in Iraq is a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. A tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and that's horrible. They were taking out the country's government, and I don't think the American government was prepared for the aftermath, the void of power, and the chaos that would occur.

The United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, similar to what they tried to do in Vietnam. They were trying to push out Communists and uphold or implement democracy. The US government should have known that it would be a long and hard ordeal that probably wouldn't be a clear victory, like Vietnam.

So, when you put something on the internet, it's public. It's completely public. You can't - I mean, as an RA, it's something I've actually had to deal with already. When you put something out there, it influences people's opinions of you. And if you're talking about blowing things up or if you're talking about shootings, someone's going to say something. You can't put that out there, put that into the world. The internet is seen by everyone. If you're friends with that person on Myspace, you get that bulletin. Obviously, it wasn't the school that got the bulletin. Someone went to the school and they have to act on that. They can't let it sit because then, God forbid something does happen, they could have prevented it. [Right]

Again, you don't know what to take seriously because some people just fool around like that. I mean, it could be like the situation we had at school. It could be an experiment that went terribly wrong for a - for a sociology class. Sorry, couldn't remember the word for a minute. And it could also be something very serious. I think what happened here was that something happened and someone overheard someone saying something in the school and then they reported it. When we finally found out who the person was, they looked through a friend of his Facebook and got very worried because there were some things on there that he may have meant as a joke but in light of the situation became very serious.

When you put stuff out into the public forum of the internet, there's really no invasion of privacy that happens. If you don't want it out there, don't put it there. If you don't want someone to find it, if you don't want someone to think something of you, you can't tell them what to think. You can't tell people what to take seriously or not. I mean, I don't think school officials should be friending their students on Myspace and Facebook and stalking and going through Facebooks and Myspaces and all those things and Xangas and Live Journals. But if it is brought to the attention of the school officials, there's really no invasion of privacy there because it's brought by someone who you gave access to it. And if there's danger they have to take it seriously.

I mean, like I said, I don't think they should be monitoring phone conversations and texts and IMs and if it's brought to their attention then it's something completely different.

Um, yeah don't. Like a teacher should not make a Facebook or a Myspace account under a different name and friend their students because then that's just, it's the same thing. I wouldn't friend my residents because frankly I don't want to know if they're going out and drinking and then posting their pictures on Facebook. Then that pops up and I have to see that and I have to do something about it. It's not my place so I don't even want that, that connection there. Um, not really.

Um, I feel like the war has been drawn out far too long. I think the initial goal was good, namely to restore democracy in another country. But I think we have long since lost sight of that goal. And we are maybe just doing it out of principle, just to prove that we are some kind of superpower in the world. I also think that the original motives were questionable, having to do with the previous disputes of George Bush's father with Saddam Hussein. So, I think... I think if the original motivation was to give democracy to a country that did not have a fair political system, then that would be a fair motivation, if there were any personal matters in it, I don't think it would have been fair. But I do think it has dragged on too long. Um, I think we achieved our purpose in the first couple of months when we started the war, I think that was a statement in itself. But the fact that it has lasted for over a year, several years, I just think it's way too drawn out. 

Um, yeah, I think, um, I mean, if our goal was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, then that's a just purpose, and that's a good reason for the war. But I don't think, I think our reason over time has deteriorated and been misunderstood. It seems like we're still at war for the sake of going to war, and we don't want to come out of this thing without a decisive end, a victory or something. 

Um, yeah, I do think it has gone on long enough, and it should stop. I mean, there comes a point when their government, their officials are going to have to fend for themselves anyway, and I think that time has come. We have long since been draining our own economy, spending billions of dollars when we have our own wars on our own turf, such as poverty and so on, that we should be spending that money on. I think it's a drain on our economy for a purpose that's long since been drawn out. 

Yeah, I mean, they're spending billions and billions of dollars, and war is not something that should be in our budget for the long term. There are things obviously like poverty or internal improvements, you know, um, public roads or anything dealing with schools, we certainly have a lot of problems funding things like that. Healthcare, that I think that money could be much better spent on. Right now that money’s being spent to have some of our own citizens killed in a foreign country in a war that we've lost the cause for.

I think that's it.

Can I ask a question to clarify this? Um, it was prevented because someone went online and found that there was something like that. O okay. Um, no, I don't think that's an invasion of privacy. On sites like Myspace, if I mean, if you post information on the internet, it's pretty much available for everyone to see. And I understand on Myspace you know, you have to have someone else be a member in order to see someone's profile. You might need to, you know, be their friend or something like that. But if that's the case, you've accepted that person as your "friend" so they can see it. You're giving them permission to see your profile. So, I mean, anytime you put information on the internet, you pretty much have to understand that a lot of people are going to see that. So if I think that was actually good that somebody saw that and was able to prevent a life from being lost.

Hum. Um, that's tough because I mean obviously you can't have one person sitting around all day looking at everybody's different profiles of all the students in the school to prevent that. But then it becomes some sort of discrimination if they think, "Oh let's look at the bad kids and make sure they're not up to anything". Um, I mean, I don't think it would really be right to go and have somebody's job be to look at peoples' profiles. But I guess it all depends on like what situation they came across that profile, or was someone just randomly looking at peoples' and just randomly happened to see that, or were they actually looking for, you know, some sort of evidence that the student was planning something. So I don't really know.

Sure. Um, well, um, like, I mean I I don't have a Myspace personally but I have a Facebook. I do. It bothers me that I know that there's creepy people out there who can see things about me. And I saw something on tv once that was about this. Um, this man who just, he was just trying to prove how he can get information so easily and he went onto this girl's profile and got her screen name right away and was talking to her on instant messenger in like you know less than a minute and got her to meet with him. And I mean personally I certainly wouldn't meet with someone like that. But I have had people in my classes who I don't recognize their screen names, but they IM me and they know that it's me. And it's hard because you think that they know your interests, they know what you look like. Sometimes if you put your class schedule they know where you are during the day, who your friends are. They pretty much know a lot about you. All sorts of photos. And I tried to limit what I put up there, but at the same time, the whole point I think, the reason I have one is so you know I can communicate with some of my friends. I don't want to limit it too much. So it's a tricky issue because I only accept people I know. I mean, you never know really who can look at what. So.

Hum, uh, well, I heard my roommate was telling me that her, um, high school, there was this whole issue about how students were banned from having Myspace by the school and that struck me as a little bit strange, like I wasn't sure how, how high school officials had the power to tell their students that they weren't allowed to have a Myspace. And I don't know if that's really a privacy issue, but I think, I don't really know, how they had the right to tell people. That's the only other thought I can think of.


Yes.

We only have this and then one more time that I need to talk about the Iraq War. I mean I feel hypocritical talking about it. I mean I hate to say you know, I hate to join the bandwagon of people that are like, oh I was against it from the beginning. Um, I was but like it’s not really important anymore. Cause just the general consensus everywhere was that it was a bad idea except within the administration because they don’t want to admit that they were wrong. And um, I mean you just have to look at like the recent polls. They’ve done United States polls, they’ve done Iraqi polls, they’ve done global polls, and I mean no like about seventy five to eighty percent of the population of the world thinks that it was a bad idea, eighty percent of Iraqis. Um, seventy percent of the troops that are over there, like the U.S. troops that are over there right now think it was a dumb idea and that we should pull out within the year. Um, I don’t know, it’s just been a complete disaster from before we even came in. It was already a disaster and now pulling out is also going to be a disaster. There’s really no easy way to go about really anything involving the Middle East anymore. Um, I mean I think it’s just, just the culture clash between like the United States and the Middle Eastern states. I mean it’s just too big a gap and for like this administration to understand or previous administrations. And they think that they can just like bring democracy into an area where it shouldn’t exist. Like that’s not the way that, um, this totally different group of people would choose to run their lives. I mean sure Saddam was a bad guy, I don’t think anyone’s like arguing that he’s not, but I mean you have to weigh the pros and cons before you invade a country that’s going to, you know, turn into just a complete disaster, just like quicksand from when we went over there. Um, I don’t even know what to say about it. Um, I don’t really see a reason at all to stay in there. Um, I mean I’m sure the administration is thinking some hopeful ideas as to why it’s better to stay in there, um, and you know the problems that might arise from us pulling out. I don’t agree with them. I’ve yet to hear like a legitimate reason why we should stay in any longer than we should. Um, if they want to do it gradually over the course of a year or maybe a little longer than a year, um, I guess I wouldn’t really have a problem with that. But, I just don’t see a reason why we shouldn’t just leave now. Um, I mean I read this statistic a little while ago that eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year and at least a quarter of them think that we should just leave now. And like these, these are the people that we’re trying to save, like that we’re trying to help, telling us to leave. Um, you know I think they might know better than that. And at least if we ask them should we leave and they say yes then you know it’s not on us if something happens. You know if it completely goes to shit we could be like well we were going to stay in but you guys made the decision not to. Um, and then you know at least we’ll, I mean if we decide to help out after that we’ll at least be the good guys. Kind of, not really, no. We’ll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but, you know, it’ll be better than you know where we are, where we stand right now. Um, yeah, uh, no.

I feel that gender discrimination is still a problem in the United States. And it's not just against women. I think it has to do with the specific field of work you are in. I mean, overall, I think women have it harder because of the glass ceiling. Even though equality is supposed to exist, most people have a hard time working under a woman if they are a man, just because of how society has been raised for so long. And so women often see a job they can reach, and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't elect to promote them to that position just because historically, women aren't usually seen in the upper echelons of the business world. And um, I guess the same thing goes for men, and for other industries like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent. It's really uncommon to have a male parent staying at home, and a lot of times people look down on that because society thinks, "Oh, well, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the money maker of your family. Why are you staying at home?" And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them, and maybe the wife has the better job, and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down on that.  And then in the fashion industry, um a lot of times people won't really take males seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion, um, I guess have different lifestyles, and so if you have the typical lifestyle and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, wait, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really know what our situation is like like these other guys." And so depending on what field of work you're in, I feel like there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset, and obviously, we have come a long way from the 1800s, leaps and bounds. But change is really slow, so I feel that if we continue working at the pace we are now because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world, and it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. And just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh, wait, maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works," and um, and then for like fashion, people will be like, "Oh, wait, maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff." And so they do know like where I'm coming from. So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um, saying like the qualities of them because if you force it people are going to resist. And I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that, so I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist, and we've come a long way and change takes time. Yes, um, well I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you go to have yourself, like you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world, and even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like, "Well, how do I know you're really what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?" So, yeah, so sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don't know, I guess that'd be another example, um, not really.

Well, my understanding is that they didn't legalize it. They decriminalized it.  Hmm, that took it down from a criminal offense to, uh, something like a traffic ticket. You know, something you just get cited for rather than having to get booked and arrested and brought in and all of that. Um, and I think that if someone gets caught and gets cited for that, then you know, for the purposes of job interviews and all sorts of things like that, those types of ramifications which are usually like the worst of having a drug charge would, I mean usually the worst ramifications of having a drug charge, well, depending on the charge. At least for a marijuana charge. One thing that a lot of kids worry about, a lot of people worry about are the future ramifications and those don’t necessarily go away when it’s decriminalized. But at the same time there is an argument that, uh, I mean it costs a lot to arrest people and to bring them in and to book them and to house them and then to let them go. And then it costs a lot, you know to have them come into court once, maybe twice, maybe three times and then appoint a public defender and then you have to pay the judge and then the state attorney’s office has to pick up the charge and basically press the charges. I mean all of that stuff costs a lot to do. And um, I mean so, when you’re looking at municipalities that are financially in trouble, I mean a lot of them just philosophically aren’t willing to make that kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them. Like a lot of communities are rightfully so against marijuana that they don’t want to do that. But in a place like Denver where people tend to be more on the kind of open, I have to use the word liberal, but you know what I mean, kind of uh, kind of thought track, then I think it’s totally fine. And I’m sure that their municipality has a lot more money now that they can spend on public education, that they can spend on like social programs for the elderly and that they can spend on, you know, food programs for the homeless people. Um, I mean so, I think it’s, it’s important because I mean marijuana isn’t something that you just want out and out to be everywhere, all over the streets and stuff. Um, I mean for a variety of reasons, but there’s this whole like financial element to it as well. Other reasons why it shouldn’t necessarily, well, no, I mean I, I don’t know how I would feel about, well because if it were totally like legalized, I guess you could make it like cigarettes where it could be sold in gas stations and people would be smoking it everywhere. Then I mean, I guess a lot of people would be like smoking and driving, and um, it still is like taboo in our society, in a lot of places and a lot of contexts, uh, to smoke marijuana. So, to have it out in the open like that, I feel like it would just be awkward to a lot of people. Um, and, sorry what?  The volume on the microphone is kind of low. Um, I don’t really know, um, I think in general alcohol has more debilitating effects on your motor skills. Um, but I think in general marijuana for a lot of people has a more adverse effect on their lifestyle as opposed to just their decision-making motor skills. I mean, but they, they both have their adverse effects and I mean they, I feel like when it comes to substances in general, like no two people really react the same way. I mean, and then people, some people have personalities that are just more normal and they just kind of go balls to wall with everything they have, and then some people know how to exercise moderation and then some people don’t. So it, I guess that makes it really hard to generalize about the substance when people react different ways, but I definitely think that they both have their own adverse effects. Um yeah, uh, no, I don’t.

I would say yes because a lot of the things they do are very traditional, like they’ve done the same things for long periods of time, and it’s good to be rooted in tradition, but it’s also important to be adaptable to change. I guess a lot of Catholics believe they have to go to church every week and they’re very strict on how things are done. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on people who don’t follow the doctrine to a tee and they don’t accept people who aren’t exactly perfect Catholics. They also don’t accept people of other religions. Like, for example, my dad was an Episcopalian and my mom was a Catholic, and they wouldn’t marry my parents in the Catholic Church because of my dad’s religion. And that’s not really being tolerant of other religions. We always learned to love others, that’s a Catholic teaching, but it’s hypocritical to say to love others and then not accept them in that way. So I feel like a lot of Catholic doctrine tells you to do things, but then Catholic practice goes against it because it’s so outdated, but they continue to stick with it anyway. I don’t think that would necessarily influence it. I mean, I personally think it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, but as I don’t think that would necessarily deter them from their pedophilic behavior, because it’s just a different realm. It might, but I probably don’t think that that would be an issue. Well, I guess like people who molest children probably would do that regardless of whether they had a spouse or not, because it’s a child which is different than a spouse. So if you’re going to do something like that, you’re probably going to do it whether or not you’re married. Like, I don’t think allowing priests to be married would prevent those things from happening. I think that would probably happen regardless.

Um, I haven't really made up my mind about this issue yet. So, I can't say if either side is right or wrong. But I believe that this is the trickiest topic we're facing today because something so close between separation of church and state and how to define marriage is something that is very hard to do without offending anyone.

So, I don't know, I think that... all civil unions... I don't know whether marriage should be looked at... and... how it should be defined by the government... Since it is a sacrament like considered... Well, people wouldn't get tax breaks... Or... looked at in any specific way by the government if they were baptized... And... so... If you're married, I think they should just look at it as a civil union... Because... that's what it is... It's two people... They shouldn't have separation of church and state... They shouldn't look into like well what kind of marriage was it... Two people got united... So... and... the fact that gay marriage... I mean... that would just... Oh, two people you got a civil union...

Um... Well, if all the states can come to a logical conclusion then they should push to make it federal law. But... a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is just ridiculous. It is... something like the constitution shouldn't just be amended for something... I mean, it is a very big cause for certain people... But... it's not large enough that it should be a constitutional amendment.

It's just not important enough to amend the constitution... to define... to ban gay marriage. Simply put...

Uh... No.

Um, I was actually raised in a Christian home, so homosexuality is kind of a grey area for me. Because I have a lot of gay friends. Um, I think I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, but I think it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue. However, I believe that it should be something that each state decides on its own, instead of, um, like, the president deciding for the whole country.

Um, like a lot of states are democratic and, and a lot of states are republican. Obviously, democratic states are going to push for gay marriage, and, and if you're living in a democratic state, then you know, obviously, how that state feels about that position. And, and I don't think that you're necessarily in a position to disagree with that decision if a state does decide to legalize gay marriage, because you kind of chose to live there. You know, so I, like, I think, I don't, I think that homosexuals should be given the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel as though it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state.

Well, I kind of already answered that, but, um, yeah, I don't feel as though, um, Bush should be allowed to, um, decide, um, um, that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to the, um, individual states as to whether they want to legalize it. I don't agree with his ban on it.

Um, I just, I just don't think, like, I don't think that, like, Bush doesn't live in every single state. So, he shouldn't be able to decide how each state wants to run, um, run itself, I guess, I don't know, um, so, I think that, um, some things should be left up to, um, each individual state. Plus, he's going to be out of office in like, what, two years, and if a democratic president decides that he wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, like, it's just going to go back and forth. It should just be up to each individual state because they're the ones that are going to have to live with that decision, not the president.

No, I don't.

Um, no, I don't at all. Um, let's see. I figure Myspace is a public thing, and a bulletin board. You know, if you look at the definition, then you know, that's basically to post for the public to see or others to see, whatever you're trying to get at. And, if you post that on the internet, you know, you have to realize that people will be seeing that, whether it be school officials or not. So, in my opinion, I feel as though the school officials seeing that, they had every right to see it because even if they weren't doing it underneath the school's name, they could have still accessed it through their homes. Um, but yeah, with something preventing a school shooting, you know, as long as it saves the lives of students, which is a responsibility of the school system, I think that's perfectly fine. Um, let me see here. Like, um, you know, if they go on the internet like on Myspace just to see if students are drinking, smoking, or doing stuff they're not supposed to be doing, they go on there just specifically to catch students and get them in trouble. And I feel as though that is an invasion of privacy. But, um, I feel as though as long as they save lives or make the school a better and safer place, I don't think that's an invasion at all. Should I elaborate more on that?

Yeah, um, alright. Well, um, hmm, it's a lot easier to express yourself a lot longer when you're writing, but alright, well, like what I was saying, it is a public thing, and with a student posting something on Myspace and not expecting to get in trouble, that's ridiculous. Um, everything, like, I'm worried to post stuff like even through emails. Um, like if I have something not good about somebody to say, I don't ever say that on an email because I'm afraid somebody somehow will pick that up, and you know, everything like everything nowadays comes back and, you know, bites you in the butt I guess you could say. Um, like, you know, if you do something while you're a college student, then you grow up to be some important guy, they will like find an email that you sent somehow, and like once it's on the internet, it's always on the internet, and, um, you know, if you do something like that there's no way of getting out of it; you will get in trouble. And I don't, it wasn't an invasion at all of privacy because, you know, like I said before, and well, that's basically all I've been saying was it's a public thing, and, um, I don't know, let's see here.

 Um, like I had said before, I don't feel as though they should go on the internet just to catch students, but if they have something that leads them to the point where they would be making the school system a safer place, then I feel as though that's perfectly fine for them, or um, other officials such as the police to go on, um, you know, when parents drop their students off at school, they feel as though they're dropping them off at a safe place. I've actually discussed that with a, um, a teacher of mine. I went to a public high school, and um, they say you know, we have to ensure stuff like this because like, we would do like lockdowns and stuff, and that's like in reference to the terrorist attacks. Uh, we had to be safe about that. We had like drill stuff, and even though that doesn't have anything to do with the well I mean it kind of does have something to do with the school shooting because um, that was in case people would come into the building I guess, um, so we, you know, we did practice that stuff um, in order to make the school a safer place, and that's just what the school officials were doing in this case; they were just making it a safer place, preventing anything bad from happening, like Columbine or something like that. Um, yeah, that's basically all I can come up with. Uh, no, that's about it.

Okay, so, at first I was all for the war because 9/11 affected me personally. I was for going over there and causing as much havoc as they did here. I think because it was such an emotional event, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long run. We kind of just went over there unprepared without a plan. And I really think that it backfired on us. Um, I don't know, I was for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it did anything. I think the people there, as long as they're fighting with each other, they can't be fighting with us too. Like, I don't think us being over there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost just, I just don't care about what goes on over there with those people. I just don't care. I just think, I don't think they're human sometimes. I don't know, they fight with each other and they can't, they just can't do anything themselves. So I really don't care. Um, I don't know, we definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face over there. Um, and it's also bad because war for them is very different than war for us. They're just like savage people when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out of there. And I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. Um, we just, I think we were just more hyped up than anything. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle and, um, I just, we pretty much just went over there looking for revenge, I think, and I think President Bush just went over there because pretty much the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. And um, also I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. Um, but at the time I see where he was coming from. We really, I don't think we had a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say ok let's rebuild and that's it. So, um, I don't think we could have let it go. But I think we could have just had a better plan of what we were gonna do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, like creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't, there was no like unity. They didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with. So that's what we created in turn in there. Um, and honestly, I don't, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And um, I don't, I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on definitely long enough. Um, I don't think we're making enough progress. Like we've made progress, but not enough to stay in there. And I think no matter how long we stay in there, once we leave, it's just gonna collapse. And we can't stay over there forever. So I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying over there. No. Okay.

The war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war before invading Iraq. I think there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality, the two didn't have much to do with each other. But the government made it seem that way and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003. 

I am against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think the war in Iraq is a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. A tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and that's horrible. They were taking out the country's government, and I don't think the American government was prepared for the aftermath, the void of power, and the chaos that would occur.

The United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, similar to what they tried to do in Vietnam. They were trying to push out Communists and uphold or implement democracy. The US government should have known that it would be a long and hard ordeal that probably wouldn't be a clear victory, like Vietnam.
